List of functions in the tool collection¶

Overview¶

Below is a collection of the various functions included in this package. Detailed descriptions can be found in their respective sections.

Convert annotations in BioC formatted XML to CSV¶

ner_for_protein_structures.annotation_conversion.bioc_annotations_to_csv.main()[source]¶

This script extracts the annotations from a BioC formatted XML file along with the sentence they belong to and writes them into a tab-separated CSV file with the following column labels: anno_start, anno_end, anno_text, entity_type, sentence, section; one one CSV file for each XML file

Input

Parameters:

  • bioc-xml-dir (str()) – location of directory holding BioC XML files with annotations

  • output-dir (str()) – full path to output directory; default = current directory

Output

Returns:

<doc_id>.csv

Return type:

CSV

Convert annotations in BioC formatted XML to JSON¶

ner_for_protein_structures.annotation_conversion.bioc_annotations_to_json.main()[source]¶

This script extracts the annotations from a BioC formatted XML file along with the sentence they belong to. All the documents in a given directory are processed and their respective IDs, <unique PubMedCentral ID>, are used as key in the returned JSON dictionary. For each document entry the following keys are used for the annotations: annotations, sid, sent, section, ner. ‘ner’ contains a list of annotations for the sentence with ID sid. All documents and their annotations are saved to disk as annotations.json.

Input

Parameters:

  • bioc-xml-dir (str()) – location of directory holding BioC XML files with annotations

  • output-dir (str()) – full path to output directory; default = current directory

Output

Returns:

annotations.json

Return type:

{JSON}

Fetch fulltext, open access publications in BioC formatted XML using PubMedCentral IDs¶

ner_for_protein_structures.bioc_xml_tools.get_bioc_xml_from_pmc.main()[source]¶

This function uses a list of PMC IDs in TXT format as input to query NCBI BioNLP API and retrieve the full text BioC formated XML for each ID. This is only possible if a given ID represents an open access publication. If access is restricted in any way, then the full text can not be retrieved. The returned XML file contains the publication text formated according to BioC XML standards as develop by the BioCreative initiative.

Input

Parameters:

  • pmcid-list (list[str]) – list of PMC IDs representing open access, full text publications in PMC; in TXT format

  • output-dir (str) – full path to output directory; default = current directory

Output

Returns:

<date>_xml_<PMCID>.xml; XML file with full text for open access publication in BioC format

Return type:

XML

Run NER predictions on BioC formatted XML files with a trained model - locally¶

ner_for_protein_structures.ner_inference.run_local_inference_for_ner.main()[source]¶

This function annotates BioC formatted XML files of publications for named entities using a trained model stored locally. The input documents for which annotations are to be produced have to be provided through a pointer to the directory where they are kept. All documents have to be in BioC formatted XML. It is assumed that input BioC XML files have their file names starting with a unique ID, e.g. <PMC ID>, which will be reused to construct the output filename. Suggested naming convension for input file name is <date>_xml_<unique ID>. A pointer to the model locally has to be provided. The model directory name is assumed to match the one for the remote location on Huggingface, e.g. BiomedNLP-PubMedBERT-ProteinStructure-NER-v2.1.

Input

Parameters:

  • xml-dir (str()) – directory containing BioC formatted XML files for which annotations are to be created; files are expected to follow a naming convention of <date>_xml_<unique ID>

  • model-dir (str()) – directory containing a trained model for inference; directory name is assumed to match the remote location on Huggingface, e.g. BiomedNLP-PubMedBERT-ProteinStructure-NER-v2.1

  • model-name (str()) – model name shorthand to be used as annotator

  • output-dir (str()) – full path to output directory; default = current directory

Output

Returns:

<unique ID>_<model name>_<date>.xml; XML file with full text for open access publication in BioC format

Return type:

XML

Run NER predictions on BioC formatted XML files with a trained model - remotely¶

ner_for_protein_structures.ner_inference.run_hf_inference_for_ner.main()[source]¶

This function contacts a specified model on Huggingface through the inference API for prediction. The model on Huggingface needs to be defined and an authentication token is required. The default model is PDBEurope/BiomedNLP-PubMedBERT-ProteinStructure-NER-v2.1. The input documents for which annotations are to be produced have to be provided through a pointer to the directory where they are kept. All documents have to be in BioC formatted XML. It is assumed that input BioC XML files have their file names starting with a unique ID, e.g. <PMC ID>, which will be reused to construct the output filename. Suggested naming convension for input file name is <date>_xml_<unique ID>

Input

Parameters:

  • xml-dir (str()) – directory containing BioC formatted XML files for which annotations are to be created; files are expected to follow a naming convention of <date>_xml_<unique ID>

  • model-repo (str()) – model repo name on Huggingface, e.g. PDBEurope/BiomedNLP-PubMedBERT-ProteinStructure-NER-v2.1, which is the default

  • auth-token (str()) – Huggingface token to authenticate into inference API

  • output-dir (str()) – full path to output directory; default = current directory

Output

Returns:

<unique ID>_<model name>_<date>.xml; XML file with full text for open access publication in BioC format

Return type:

XML

Processing BioC formatted XML files to turn annotations into IOB format for SemEval calculations¶

ner_for_protein_structures.annotation_conversion.process_bioc_xml_for_performance_stats.main()[source]¶

This script extracts the annotations from a BioC formatted XML file along with the sentence they belong to and converts everything into IOB formatted sentences with annotations; IOB formatted annotations serve as input for calculating performance statistics following the SemEval procedure; optionally, an ‘annotator’ can be selected for later calculation of individual performance for either a human annotator or predictions from a trained model; a tab-separated TSV files ‘all.tsv’ acontains all annotated sentences;

Input

Parameters:

  • pmcid-list (str) – full path to BioC formatted XML files with annotations

  • output-dir (str) – full path to output directory; default = current directory

  • annotator (str) – lable/name/identifier for a particular human annotator or trained model

Output

Returns:

all.tsv; tab-separated TSV file of relevant sentences and their annotations in IOB format

Return type:

TSV

Processing BioC formatted XML files to turn annotations into IOB format for model training¶

ner_for_protein_structures.annotation_conversion.process_bioc_xml_for_training.main()[source]¶

This script extracts the annotations from a BioC formatted XML file along with the sentence they belong to and converts everything into IOB formatted sentences with annotations; IOB formatted annotations serve as input for training a transformer model for automated named entity recognition for protein structure specific terms; four files are being produced: train.tsv, dev.tsv, test.tsv, all.tsv; the first three are the different fractions used for model training and development; the last one contains all sentences and annotations

Input

Parameters:

  • pmcid-list (str) – full path to BioC formatted XML files with annotations

  • output-dir (str) – full path to output directory; default = current directory

Output

Returns:

train.tsv, dev.tsv, test.tsv, all.tsv; tab-separated TSV files of relevant sentences and their annotations in IOB format; all.tsv contains all the sentences; train.tsvis the training fraction of the processed sentences; dev.tsv is the development fraction of the sentences used during development; test.tsv is the final testing set

Return type:

TSV

Running SemEval to calculate performance statistics¶

ner_for_protein_structures.sem_eval.run_semeval_analysis.main()[source]¶

This function runs the SemEval evaluation script to calculate performance statistics as precision, recall and F1 measure for annotations coming from either an automatic system in form of predictions, or as manually created annotations. The details for the evaluation process have been published here: https://aclanthology.org/S13-2056.pdf. Two IOB formatted input files of word tokesn and corresponding labels have to be provided. One of the files represents the ground truth/gold standard to compare against. The other one contains the predicted/manually created annotations.

Input

Parameters:

  • ground-truth-IOB (str) – path to IOB formated sentence input of word tokens and labels for the ground truth/gold standard data; tab-separated .TSV/.CSV file

  • annotated-IOB (str) – path to IOB formated sentence input of word tokens and labels for the predicted/manually created data; tab-separated .TSV/.CSV file

  • validate-labels (Boulean) – True/False Boulean label on whether or not to check label integrity; default: True

  • entity-types (str) – path to .TXT file containg the entity type labels that were used to generate the IOB formatted data files

  • output-dir (str) – full path to output directory; default: current directory

Output

Returns:

<current date>_SemEval_report.txt; text file containing the score report for matches in annotations between the ground truth/gold standard and the predicted/manually created data following the SemEval scoring procedure.

Return type:

str

Converting EuropePMC/JATS style XML to BioC XML¶

ner_for_protein_structures.bioc_xml_tools.pmcxml_to_biocxml.main()[source]¶

ner_for_protein_structures
